Cf. Kissinger's "White Revolutionary" & Bismarck. Anyway, it's been a long tweetstorm as I wait for my train. Here ends the lesson 👍
Even w/those rare men who can self-moderate after spate of specific victories, they misinspire lesser men, viscerally-driven & unrestrained
Trouble is that it's effective short term but unstable long term. Nothing suggests Trump has self-moderating element for once goals achieved
The trouble with such men is that they generally think they're the first to ever discover this bluffing style. Napoleon III, case in point.
Ultimately it will end one of two ways: 1) his brash cackhandedness wears thin, and his base abandons him. 2) he does something catastrophic
relevance to his actual agenda. Credibility will become its own justification. Salisbury wrote against this style of populism back in 1850s.
(as I suspect) his visceral need for attention/dominance will compel him to follow through once bluffs start being called, regardless of
Eventually, assuming he hasn't a hierarchy of limited concrete goals to achieve, it will be his downfall. Bluff will either be called, or
All in all, whilst taking a proactive approach to defining news agenda, over time it risks greater & greater bluffs to maintain attention.
It's real strength is that it preys on structural vulnerabilities of attention-grabbing/clickbait-driven news-cycle.
Worth noting his tactic has dimishing returns once Trump's interlocutors become accustomed. Yet strategically diminishes value of criticism
Step 6. Trump walks away with 60-80%, after initially (and disingenuously) demanding 100% & importantly staying in headlines all the while.
Step 5. Cue journalistic need for rhythm & freshness, resulting in "Trump not so bad" thinkpieces. Endless angry denunciations will not sell
Step 4. Resulting policy seems comparatively less extreme, and media will anyway have already overused their indignation to whip opposition
Step 3. He modifies original outrageous policy, moderating the most calculatedly offensive/unworkable (always eye-catching) parts
Step 2. He delights in the media's outraged reaction, which habitually must become worn down over months & years.
